simone

Concerning the infant mortality rate specifically (number of deaths per 1,000 live births), irreligious countries have the lowest rates, and religious countries have the highest rates. According to the CIA World Factbook (2004), out of 225 nations, the top 25 nations with the lowest infant mortality rates were all nations containing significantly high percentages of organic atheism. Conversely, the 75 bottom nations with the highest infant mortality rates were all very religious nations without any statistically significant levels of organic atheism. 

 
 http://www.pitzer.edu/academics/faculty/zuckerman/atheism.html

 I don't see that. There were times in European history, centuries ago, when science was squashed by the church, sure. But I don't see that being the issue here, now. IM is most often an issue of basic sanitation, nutrition, and basic medicine. This is widely known, people aren't denying this in the name of religion or anything. I don't see resources that could go to solving these issues going towards religion instead.  Regardless, I have heard of some specific, but rarely practiced, issues where it could have an effect.
 The bible includes a passage about not ingesting blood. 
 Lev 3:17 [It shall be] a perpetual statute for your generations throughout all your dwellings, that ye eat neither fat nor blood. 
 A rare few Judeo-Christian sects have interpreted this as prohibiting blood transfusions, which would be necessary for some medical procedures. Without blood transfusions, other medical procedures would be more complicated with a higher chance of death.
 http://www.watchtowerinformationservice.org/gillon.htm
 
 Another example would be how some religions would balk at the idea of organ transplants from animals, like pigs. Some other options are available though, but it does complicate matters.

 Sure, there are fringe sects and whatnot. I'm sure there have been a few cases of babies dying because the parents prayed instead of seeing a doctor. I just don't see that it's a statistically significant number. And as for transfusions and organ transplants, those aren't what's needed to prevent most infant deaths. It's really basic stuff like clean water, good food, and really basic medicine. Norris and Inglehart (2004) found that 39% of those in Britain do not believe in God. According to a 2004 survey commissioned by the BBC, 44% of the British do not believe in God. According to Greeley (2003), 31% of the British do not believe in God, although only 10% self-identify as "atheist." According to Bruce (2002), 10% of the British self-identify as an "agnostic person" and 8% as a "convinced atheist," with an additional 21% choosing "not a religious person." According to Froese (2001), 32% of the British are atheist or agnostic. According to Gallup and Lindsay (1999:121), 39% of the British do not believe in God or a "Higher Power." 

 
 One thing I find intresting about this data is the discrepancy with official census results. Here you get a figure of 31% - 44% non-believers for the UK whilst the official figure is 10%. 
 I know there was a lot of people who didn't want to complete the census forms (Myself included) but it suggests a lot were non-believers.
